div1.p: Carter writes about his journey from Guayaquil, Peru and his future travel plans.

Dear Laura (Mrs Laura)
div1.p:
We left Guayaquil
yester at 5.30 P. M. I will be about 6 days get-
ting to Callao - the seaport of Lima. It is a -
question if any of us are allowed to land
before reaching Callao - i.e. until 6 days
have passed since leaving Guayaquil.
Possibly the 5 immune to y.f. may do so certainly not the
three susceptible to it. We will see the next
port at which we touch - Eten.

The trip is smooth, perfectly so except for the vi-
bration of the boat, & the weather is Cold
Whitmore has on an overcoat, as has Gorgas &
2
I have on my heavy underclothes & my dark
suit, & am even with it rather too cool
than too warm. Of course the ship's motion
make a breeze. And here we are about 6 degrees
of the Equator & Panama is 8 1/2 degrees & never
under 75° - generally 88° to 92°. It is I am sure
as cold as in Baltimore today. This winter
in the south is, the Captain tells us, an un-
commonly severe one & travel across
the Andes - from Santiago to B. Ayres is blocked.

This part is business & is for L. Jr. if she is at
home when it arrives.

(1) I want to repeat my request - in the letter
from KingstonColon, for Henry (or her) to register
see about the registry of my address in
the Western Union Office. My impression
is that It is possible that addresses are not
C1
B20
3
not allowed to be registered now. At any
rate the wireless man on the Almirante
said he could not take my message to a
code address unless the address had been
establised prior to July 1914. If so, there is
no reason why my old address
“Carterh” - which I registered. I think in 1904 or
/05 - should not again be brought to their notice
It was extant in last fall when I went to Puerto
Rico,- although w I was informed when I sent
my wireless - before we reached Jamaica
that this address was non-existent. Of course
notify me of the address registered.

If La Our itinary as now determined is
as followed. We reach Lima July 12 or 13.
The first vessel for the north leaves July 16 or 17, & on it
we reach Panama on the 22 or 23, go into
quarantine one day & take the S. S. La-
4
La Capa (U. F. Co) on the 27th for Cartagena. Pos-
sibly we may get an Italian or French Liner
a day or even two days earlier. We go first
Then the plans are alternative (a) all go to Bogo-
ta, to get the permission of the Central govern-
ment, or (b) leave some of us. Myself & Guite-
ras at, to work up the Magdalena deltu
(Carthagena: Baranquilla & Sabanilla) & Gorgas &
the rest go to Bogota-. Then all to La Guyra. &
of course Caraccas first - & back to Maracaito
& up to Cucuta - in the interior of Colum-
bia. Then to Barbados & there Catch the
Lamfort & Holt Steamer for Rio Janeiro.
Then the east coast of Brazil (Bahia & Pernambu-
co & Para) & up the Amazon to Iquitos

Possibly enough we may not have time to
make the Brazilian trip- If so we may be
able
C1
B20
5
able to return to Panama & visit Buenventu-
ra & Tumaco, on the west coast of Colum-
bia. This is advisable - but not absolutely necessary.

I tell this in detail because if L. does not
come to Panama to meet us there, she
can if she wishes judges it best arrange to come down
on the Lamfort & Holt Steamer which we
would (or may) catch at Barbadoes for
Rio. This would be from the latter part of
August to the middle or latter part of Sep-
tember - I think - within 10 days of Sept
10th, I would of course cable the name,
& date of sailing (from N. Y.) of the Steamer.

I really do not think that we will have time
to make the Brazilian trip on the leave
we have granted; but it is a (1) it is possible
that
6
we can & (2) we may have the leaves re-
added toextended - without pay - after one we I can
get one more month i.e. to Oct 20 I think - with
pay, beyond that I can not without pay.

T One reason-, the controlling one, for going by
the North Coast - first instead of by the south
was the advisability of the M Army men, keep-
ing in touch with their their Department. I thi
I think that there will be no war with Mexico - altho
although Carranza has done his best to bring
one on,- yet it is certainly possible even yet.

I am sending an article - from El Grito
- the yellowest paper in Ecuador & the most
anti-American- Indeed am sending two
- are a translation by Juan Guiteras & and are
coming out later yesterday- This one is bad e-
nough - & yet the last paragraph is a retrac-
tion of the first as far as this Commission is
concerned. The Telegrafo - is a paper of far
higher.

C1
B20
July 8/16

Three more points
(1) I rec'd at the hour of leaving Guayaquil - the
letters of yourself which I have read many
times: of Mary & of Laura. I was the more glad
that the latter had returned as you said that you
greatly missed her- All were of June 19 & all
in one envelope

(2) If Laura meets me in Panama I will
from that place - have made out a Power
of - attorney for Henry, to sign my name
so that he can deposit my service check
& draw against my account - by check

(3) There is no necessity for Laura to bring
more money than enough to reach her
point of meeting us - & a margin to allow
for accidents. I will be able if she comes
to draw against the Rockefeller Found-
B(2)
36
Foundation for her expenses. Lyster acts
as Treasurer & has exchange drawn in their
name, The Foundation owe me to date $579.33590.33
& by the against which I can draw-

- This last information will be of use only if she does
not meet Ms at Panama - but in Barba-
does.

Lyster estimates Lyster & myself estimate that
we will make Barbadoes - from sept 15 to
Oct 1st. Gorgas leave is out Oct 11 (as is Lyster's
& Whitmores) so leave would have to be exten-
ded if we take the Brazilian work this trip.
Whitmore has believes that he must return
to his position the Army medical school - by Oct 10.

My leave is up - Sept 20 - but I can get 30 days
more with pay. I would like to return from
La Guyra & take the Brazils (& Yucatan) next
year. However that is in the future
